headline: Fresh Cherry Cobbler
description: This delicious cherry cobbler is made with fresh cherries rather than canned. Pitting the cherries will be well worth it when you taste this treat.

video.description: See how to make Fresh Cherry Cobbler.
video.name: Fresh Cherry Cobbler

name: Fresh Cherry Cobbler

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Place butter in a 9x13-inch baking dish, and place in the oven to melt while the oven is preheating. Remove as soon as butter has melted, about 5 minutes.
Stir together 1 cup flour, 1 cup sugar, and baking powder in a medium bowl. Mix in milk until well blended, then pour the batter into the pan over the melted butter. Do not stir.

Rinse out the bowl from the batter, and dry. Place cherries into the bowl, and toss with remaining 3/4 cup sugar and 1 tablespoon flour. Distribute the cherry mixture evenly over the batter. Do not stir.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 50 to 60 minutes. A toothpick inserted into the cobber should come out clean.

review.reviewBody: I have made this recipe multiple times with different types of fruit: strawberries, mixed berries, apples and cherries. I have alsoused fresh or frozen fruit. It is an excellent recipe and very easy.
i thought it to be very simple ty
Ugh this was horrible!!! I only halved the sugar and kept everything else the same. I didn't over-mix it, but it came out rubbery and greasy. It was not at all like a cobbler. Very disappointed.
I would use less sugar the next time I made it—very sweet. However I did not use sour cherries so that could be the difference. Otherwise it is a very good recipe!

I made this with a mix of sweet red cherries and sweet yellow cherries, and only the ingredients given in the recipe, but definitely added more than 2 cups of cherries. It was a perfect way to use cherries picked by my grandkids when I took them cherry picking this week. Having just had my first taste of this dessert, I would definitely recommend it! It was easy to make (after the cherries were pitted), and tastes delicious!
So easy and so good! I went cherry picking, and ten pounds of cherries later, went looking for a good recipe. This one was great!

I kept trying to think of what this reminds me of. Another reviewer nailed it. Pineapple upside down cake. It was interesting to watch how the cherries and biscuit layers swapped placed. I used 3 cups of cherries. Could definitely used more. I liked it and I'm not sure if I'd make it again as I'm curious to try other recipes. All in all, very easy prep and it was quite tasty.
I did add more cherries. The guys at work liked it so much I had to make another batch for them.
pretty good but a tad sweet. also I used 1/2 tsp of vanilla.

Nobody liked this recipe. The flavor was uneven (likely because the batter poured on top of the butter doesn't evenly distribute, but moves the butter to the side) and it is much more of a cake than a cobbler. The flavors weren't not well received by my family.
I think I will use pitted cherries next time. Haha. Love this recipe.
I have this one saved as BEST CHERRY COBBLER because it is!!! I've made it several times (only add is Ceylon Cinnamon) and it is always a huge hit!
delicious and so easy!
This is super easy and the bomb.com. I made it with whole wheat pastry flour and monk fruit sweetener and it was still YUM. Make it, you won’t regret it.

I made it exactly as the recipe called for. Looked great but it came out of the pan like glue. In fact I'm sure I spent more calories scrapping out the mess than what little my body took in by eating what little I was able to unstick. I'm pretty sure this is a recipe for wood glue.
Easy, delicious. I am a family of 5. It was completely gone the same day I Made it. The kids topped theirs with vanilla ice cream and whipped cream(homemade) while it was warm. Fabulous!!!
Next time I’ll cut the sugar in half. It was a little too sweet for my husband. I was fine with the extra sugar
I was searching for a recipe to replace my grandmother’s which is lost. This isn’t it. Too much sugar! Also, I would bake in a 9” pan.
It came out ok, my bad I used Stevia to sweeten do it wasn't as sweet, but it was still good.
I made this the first time with fresh cherries, and it was awesome, then I made it for a second time with the canned cherries and was okay, but the fresh cherries are definitely better.
I made the cobbler using fresh sweet cherries, so I only used 1/2 cup of sugar. Otherwise I followed the directions completely, and it came out absolutely delicious
It was very good but I would add a little less sugar than it calls for if your cherries are not super tart.

This recipe was simple and easy to follow. I substituted a gluten free flour mix and lactose free milk as I currently have digestive issues I used sweet cherries so I added just a 1/4 cup of sugar to them.
I also substituted brown sugar throughout as that's what I had on hand. The end result looked and 
tasted good, but the flour mix made the batter rather thick and somewhat hard to pour and reach the ends of the pan. I removed some of the melted butter so I could gently spread the batter a little. Next time I make this or something similar, I'll either try adding a little more milk or a different version of this flour mix brand.

Y'All! This is SO GOOD! Faster and easier than my other recipe and SO YUMMY! Probably my new go-to. We've already eaten half of it and the oven isn't yet cool! I doubed the cherries, as per our taste preference, and it is simply super. Thank you Miranda!
Definitely not enough fruit and it came out a little dry. Perhaps letting the cherries sit for a bit with the sugar to create some juices.
I made this and OMG!! Definitely going to use with other fresh fruit.
Easy (except for pitting the cherries). Pretty. But too sweet!
Made the recipe as written and it turned out great! Exactly what I wanted from a cobbler and I didn't miss the pie filling can one bit.

Not a great recipe. Many that are much better. Too much sugar. Cut it in half and still rather sweet. I question the amount of milk. The cake was soggy. Would not use this recipe again. Surprised at the many good reviews.
I did use canned cherries and some brown sugar and this was great!
love it, can use my fresh cherries. Quick easy and really good.
So disappointed. Must say I made the changes suggested by one of your readers. It came out flat! Shouldn't there have been an egg in it? Family ate it but I won't make it again. So sorry.

The hardest part it pitting the cherries. I don’t have a pitter, so I used the bottle and chopstick method. I found that putting the bottom of cherry upward and pushing the seed out through the top of the cherry into the bottle didn’t take as much of cherry with it. The recipe sure is fast and easy. I gave half to my neighbor, who also loved it. I made it a second time and made a mistake. I checked on it at about 42 minutes and it looked like it was about to burn. I took it out and it was edible but not as pretty as the first time. Whoops! Realized I had used baking soda instead of baking power. Was a lot harder to clean the dish too. Made again This time I used 3/4 cup sugar in mix instead of 1 cup. And mixing with the cherries used 1/2 cup instead of 3/4 cup of sugar. Still good. Just not as sweet. Cooking in my oven at 350 degrees, it was done in 46 minutes. Definitely have your vanilla ice cream with it! This is a very easy fast recipe . Thank you for sharing.

This was very good. I used freshly picked cherries. Crust was delicious, and everyone who tasted it like it. However, I like my cobbler to be more juicy. I think either a smaller pan or more cherries. I am going to try a deep dish cherry pie recipe, next.
Amazing! Very similar to a recipe my mom used. I grew up on an orchard and we used this recipe with blackberries and peaches.
This is my go to favorite cobbler. I like a lot of 'crust' so I usually double the crust amount while leaving the cherries the same.
Everyone loved it, very simple and delicious.

DELICIOUS! Followed a few suggestions from others... I used 1/2 white sugar and 1/2 Sugar in the Raw and added 1 tsp vanilla to batter. I doubled cherry mixture...next time I'll drop back to 1-1/2 amount of cherry mixture.

So easy and amazing how perfect it comes out everytime. I actually froze bags of cherries with the stem and pit. On the day before I plan to make the cobbler I thaw the cherries and it makes the best cobbler. I have made this several times and again it has come out perfect if you follow the recipe.

It’s not crumble, it is more like a pancake texture. 
For me it was just too sweet, I will reduce the amount of sugar next time.

Super easy to prepare and fast for a quick dessert.

This turned out well in spite of using sweet cherries (I didn't have tart ones on hand). To compensate for this I cut back on sugar like others suggested, but also made a lemon frosting to drizzle over the top when done - this added the tartness I was missing to complement the sweet, and cherry and lemon flavors pair well in general... To make the lemon frosting I simply added lemon juice to some powdered sugar and stirred it up.

The first time I tried it it was very cakey (if that's a thing). I am trying it with a tsp lime juice in the cherries and 1.25 tsp baking soda in the batter and in the oven it is proofing up more and giving a crisper exterior thus far it looks good. I may try oatmeal with it next time just for kicks.

Made this according to directions except for doubling recipe. It's way too sweet for my taste. Next time I'll cut half the sugar out of crust and half out of fruit. I can tell if I'd done this it's a great recipe. It's good now, very easy.

Ty for the recipe I’ve been trying to figure out what else to do with my cherries. I’ve actually got a 25ft tall tart cherry tree on my property. I’ve already got enough cherry jelly & jam to last me the whole year. Plus I’ve got enough cherry pie filling in jars to get me though the year. But I’ve always wanted something else to do with them. Now I do ty so much for the recipe.
I used 3 cups of bing cherries so I reduced the sugar. I liked it but I thought the dough part was a bit gummy. Thanks for sharing your recipe.

I don't recommend this. I did as others advised - added cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla to the batter, reduced the butter, reduced the sugar - and it was just okay. The dough really comes out tough, like it would be better eaten with a knife and fork. A waste of good cherries, IMHO.
i forgot to add the sugar on top but added it when it was cooking but it turned out fine

Followed all the directions with all of the ingredients, including cherries picked at an orchard a couple days before.

I checked it at 35 mins in the oven (following the 350° F instructions) and it was already dark brown so I took it out. My oven is good at keeping heat, so I would start checking on it around the 30 min mark. Really tasty!

LOVE THIS RECIPE! DIDN'T HAVE SOUR CHERRIES SO I USED SWEET AND IT WAS PRETTY AND DELICIOUS. I WILL BUY SOUR CHERRIES NEXT TIME AND WILL ALSO TRY CANNED PEACHES.
IT IS WELL WORTH TAKING THE TIME TO PIT THE CHERRIES AS OTHER THAN THAT THE RECIPE TAKES NO TIME AT ALL.

This dish is wonderful. I made some of the changes suggested by others: used ½ cup of sugar in the flour mixture; added 1 tsp vanilla and 1 tsp cinnamon; used 4 cups of cherries. I will make it again.
Great recipe, after making it the first time we cut back on the sugar a little on the dry mix and the berries. But still an easy and great recipe.

Made cherry cobbler for the first time in my life at 2 AM during an episode of insomnia when I realized our cherries were about to go bad. Stayed up talking to my roommate while pitting the cherries, and together we waited eagerly in the results. It was delectable, but very sugary! Next time I may try to reduce the sugar content a tad. Absolutely will be a next time. Cheers
This recipe was really good!! The only things i changed was i cut the butter in half it was way to much!!
I’m not sure if the recipe was right, I followed it with the batter on the bottom and it was dense and doughy. All of the pictures look like the batter is baked on the top...
I didn't change anything. Everyone loved it and I would definitely make it again .
Looks yummy

This is a salty sweet vacation for your mouth! Soooooo good. I substituted 1/2 cup of the sugar in the cobbler with 12 packets of truvia. Tasted great! I also didn’t mix the cherries with 3/4 cup sugar. I only used 1/2 cup. Still delicious! I wouldn’t decrease the butter because the salty endnote really makes this spectacular.
Wonderful recipe!

I had fresh sweet cherries that needed to be used. Fortunately, I found this recipe. I did increase the cherries to 4 cups; however, I think next time, I would maybe use 3 cups and cut some in half. I also added, per other reviewers, cinnamon & vanilla extract to the batter and cut the sugar in both the batter and the cherry mixture. Cooked perfectly in 50 minutes; removed and sprinkled top w/ brown sugar and put under broiler for a couple minutes to caramelize. I used 13x9 baking dish; maybe, next time I will use smaller dish for it to be thicker. Was delicious served warm with vanilla ice cream. This would also be a great recipe for blueberries or peaches or apples.
This was so easy, and turned out fantastic. This will be my go-to recipe for any fresh fruit cobbler that I make! Wouldn't change a thing!

Cherries lacked flavor 
Could be user error
Definitely cook for 45 min instead of 60
Similar to peach cobbler recipe and consistency
Ice-cream compliments it well

-Catherine and Josiah
I think there is too much butter. It taste too greasy. I will try to cut the butter next time. It is easy to make.

My sister-in-law and I made this for a BBQ night dessert and it was delicious! Can’t wait to make it again and try using other fruits. 

The only alterations to this recipe were that we used sweet cherries, and we sliced them in half because they were too large to spread out and cover the dish.

It tasted good, but the proportions were off for me. I'm not sure what I did wrong, but the cobbler was way too buttery (and I love butter). I had to pour off about a quarter cup before I served it. Also, it took more than an hour to bake. Again, I think I must have done something wrong, though I did follow the directions. The cobbler tastes good, but doesn't look like the picture, and it's more cake than cobbler.

It came out GREAT!!!! The ingredients are spot on! As a personal preference, I added 1 tsp. of Vanilla extract and 1/4 tsp. of Almond extract. I also, doubled the cherry amount to 4 Cups instead of the recommended 2. I read all the reviews beforehand, and changed up my recipe assembly slightly. After melting the butter in the preheating oven, I added my 'coated' cherry mixture to the butter, with the cherries now being begun as the starting layer of the dish. Next, I drizzled the batter over the cherry/butter mixture. It baked a perfect 60 minutes in my oven. In the last 10 of the 60, I scattered brown sugar atop the mixture and baked. It was excellent! The finished dish was a perfect ratio of cherries to caramelized crust consistency. It was SO easy. I will definitely be making it again.

A yummy dessert and super easy to make. There aren't many recipes for fresh-picked cherries, but this was a great way to feature this delicious fruit! I had all of the ingredients on hand already and it worked perfectly. My only complaint was that it becomes very gooey and sticky on the bottom of the pan, but that also means that it's extra sticky and delicious! A little whipped cream or vanilla ice cream and you have a sweet treat!

Like other reviewers, I added more cherries - a generous 4 cups and loved the result. I also added a heaping teaspoon of cinnamon. I just wish fresh tart cherries were available year round so we could make this wonderful dessert whenever we wanted!

This recipe is fantastic, it turned out just the way a cobbler should turn out, moist and lovely texture with crispy edges and just the right amount of filling. That having said, I did make some changes to this recipe. First, I doubled the amount of flour, cherries, milk, and baking soda. I kept the amount of sugar the same but it could have used a tablespoon or two more. Second I did stir the cherries just a bit after pouring onto the batter to make a more even consistency. I kept the baking time the same, and it turned out near perfect. I have no idea how the original recipe would turn out with all that butter and only I cup flour. I would not try it that way, I will continue to double the flour, milk and fruit
Simply Delicious!

This is the exact recipe my mammaw made. The preparation was only slightly different in that she would heat up the oven with a skillet in the oven, then prepare the batter and fruit. When the skillet and oven were nice and hot she would put a stick of butter in to melt for about 5 minutes, then add the batter and then finally the fruit on top, never stirring. The batter bakes up all around the fruit. So glad I found this recipe, thank you for sharing!

This was really good. I had to tweak the recipe a bit as I did not have sour cherries. I used three cherry varieties, Bing, Rainier, and Strawberry Rainier. I added about a teaspoon of vanilla to the batter as well as a pinch of salt. When tossing the cherries with the flour and sugar mixture, I used half as much sugar and added a couple of dashes of cinnamon. I turned out absolutely fabulous and everyone who had it asked for the recipe.

Holy butter and sugar! I used 1/2 cup instead of a cup and it was still super sweet. I used a 9x9 instead of a 9x13 but kept all ingredients the same. It came out great except there was way too much butter. This must have been due to the 9x9, but judging on how much butter there was I think there would have still been too much even with a 9x13. So yes, this is a great easy recipe, and of course it tastes good because its drenched in butter and sugar.
I wasn't sure if I melted the butter right (I melted it completely until it was a liquid), but it was a hit with my family! So simple and quick! I would definitely make it again :)

I used red cherries - cut the sugar on those to 1/4 cup. I used 2/3 cup sugar in the cake portion, added cinnamon. Added vanilla to the melted butter - also cut the butter down by 2 tablespoons. I also cut the cherries in half. 

It came out amazing. Perfectly sweet.
Added quick oats on the top and some ginger, cinnamon and nutmeg in the cherries

This cobbler is awesome. the batter baked just the way I like it, a little chewy. I also used less sugar and added cinnamon, vanilla, and almond extract as recommended by others, to the batter. I increased amt of cherries to 4 cups.
FYI. I didn't have enough all purpose flour so I made up the difference with almond flour. It turned out fine.

I love this recipe and agree tweaks are good to enhance its overall enjoyment y each individual. What makes it great is it is flexible! The base recipe it there and is great! Hats off to the chef! That said, I have a question for everyone. I use frozen sour cherries I get from Michigan and of course, four cups of frozen cherries is way different from un-frozen and when thawed, there is a tremendous amount of liquid. I fear using all of the liquid from the defrosted cherries in the recipe worruying it will be runny, but some is necessary. Any ideas on how to adjust this matter so it works best?
This is the easiest and most delicious recipe. You don't have to use cherries! Any berry will work. I used a mix of fresh blueberry, strawberry and blackberries.
Great
This so DELICIOUS! I loved it! Except for pitting the cherries, it was easy and fast and fabulous.
More a cross between cherry dump cake and cherry cobbler. But delicious just the same.

Great recipe. I doubled everything except the butter and sugar but wish I had doubled the sugar. Despite using sweet cherries, it lacked the sweetness I was anticipating. Next time, I will just double it all. I may also cut the bigger cherries in half. I added cinnamon and vanilla to the batter as suggested and used half brown sugar and half white sugar. Doubled, this made a thick, full cobbler in the 9x13 and is packed with cherries. After reading the edges get almost deep fried due the butter, I gently mixed just the edges after pouring the batter in. My edges were crisp but not tough or fried. Overall, it's delicious and I will be making again.

If I could give it zero stars I would. Followed exactly and this receipe is a disaster!Very hard toffee on the bottom. This is not a cherry cobbler. Waste of ingredients. Threw it out. Do Not recommend.

I really liked this classic cobbler recipe, as I prefer ones in which you place the fruit on top of the batter. I halved the recipe and used coconut oil instead of butter, as I'm lactose intolerant and typically substitute coconut oil for butter in most recipes. Because I was trying to use up past-their-prime cherries, I had more than a cup - more like 1 1/3 cups. I used a glass pie pan. I've never used cherries before in a cobbler, and I was very pleased with the result.

EXCELLENT! I made the recipe according to directions except I added more cherries than the recipe indicated and increased the amount of flour added to the cherries. I didn't increase the sugar, though, and the sweetness was perfect. I made it for a potluck, and everyone loved it! My baking pan was slightly bigger than the recipe recommended, and the crust was a little thin. The next time I make it, I think I'll double the crust ingredients to make it thicker. Other than that, it was delicious! This recipe would be great with plums, apples, blueberries, or any other type of fruit used for crisps and crumbles. Definitely making it again!
The flavour was nice, but I didn't like how greasy it was. Nobody else seemed to mind however, and liked it, so I'll probably make it again (I just won't eat it).
This has got to be one of the tastiest things I've ever eaten.
This was excellent! Doubled the recipe and as per other reviews added extra cherries. Fantastic dessert.
Wasn't a fan of this recipe. Not a good cobbler, consistency was gummy, edges were tough, overly buttery. Would not make again
I agree with others that less sugar would make this better. It's not like a traditional cobbler but still easy and good.

Sorry, we didn't care for this. My 4 year old wouldn't even eat it, and when it comes to sweets she eats everything. This was like a cake with some cherries scattered across the top and a chewy, crispy caramel-like layer all around the edge that was kinda odd. If you try this, you'll want to at least double the cherries.

I purchased a basket of sour cherries at a local farmers market. I followed recipe exactly except I added a teas of almond extract to the cherry mixture. I baked in a 10 inch round tart pan for 50 min. It looked pretty but there was spill over in the oven so protect the oven floor with foil. Tastes delicious!

I followed recipe except for using frozen cherries. I never stray from the original recipe the first time I make it but I only had access to frozen cherries and felt like making dessert. I agree that the pan size is too big and makes for a flat cobbler. Even though it tasted good it had crispy edges and the rest was gooey like a custard and not the usual cobbler texture. Maybe its because I used frozen cherries? The flavor was good but the I think I will stick to a more traditional cobbler next time.
This is a great recipe, and so simple to make. It came out just right. Like others, I added more cherries (4 cups total) a teaspoon of vanilla and a dash of cinnamon. Delicious!
I did not like this recipe. (Sorry!) The cobbler crust was chewy and thin and it did not taste good. :-( I do not recommend it.

Anything with 1/2 c butter and only 1 cup flour cannot be expected to become cobbler. And this recipe is no exception. Ended up with an overly sweet (after I had already cut down the sugar) - syrupy gloppy mess of cherries with minimal dough with the whole mess swimming in a lake of butter. Blecchhh.
Very delicious! But double the cherries...it'll be even better.

Ive made this several times and its perfect every time. Easy to make. You can pretty much sub out any fresh fruit too. Its not overly sweet and the salt from the butter is really nice constrast against the fruit. The edges basically fry in butter making them crunchy. This is my go to cobbler now any time I gave fresh peaches or cherrys on hand.

I made this for a Special dinner with guests. Everyone enjoyed it, but I personally felt disappointed in the texture of the cobbler. It felt more like a sponge cake shortbread thing with not enough goo. Ice cream or whip cream made it better. Next time I will look for something more traditional with dough on top or a crisp topping.
